story1.title: Finding Hope After Ten Years
story1.author: Michael R.
story1.excerpt: After a decade of struggling with alcohol addiction, I found a path to recovery that changed everything.
story1.content:
I spent ten years of my life in a cycle of alcohol abuse that I couldn't seem to break. Every morning I would wake up with the same regret, the same promises to myself, and by evening, the same behaviors would return. It wasn't until I lost my job and nearly my family that I finally admitted I needed help.

The journey wasn't easy. I went through detox, then intensive outpatient therapy, and finally found a community of people who understood what I was going through. The tools I learned in therapy—identifying triggers, developing coping mechanisms, practicing mindfulness—gradually became part of my daily routine.

Today, I'm five years sober. I've rebuilt my career, restored trust with my family, and found purpose in mentoring others who are just beginning their recovery journey. If you're struggling right now, please know that change is possible. It won't happen overnight, but with the right support and commitment, you can find your way to a life beyond addiction.

story2.title: Recovery as a Single Parent
story2.author: Jessica T.
story2.excerpt: Balancing recovery with the responsibilities of single parenthood taught me strength I never knew I had.
story2.content:
When I entered recovery for prescription drug addiction, my biggest fear was failing my two young children. As a single parent, I had no partner to lean on, and the guilt of how my addiction had already affected my kids was overwhelming.

My journey began with intensive outpatient treatment. I was fortunate to find a program that offered childcare, which made it possible for me to attend regular sessions. Learning to process my emotions without substance use while still managing the daily stress of parenting was incredibly challenging.

What made the difference for me was connecting with other parents in recovery. We shared childcare, offered each other emotional support, and celebrated both recovery milestones and parenting victories. I also found that being honest with my children, in age-appropriate ways, helped heal our relationship.

Three years into recovery, I can say that the skills I've learned have made me a better parent. I'm present with my children in ways I never could be before. My recovery hasn't just saved my life—it's given my children the mother they deserve.
